columns.text: In this problem, we need to determine how much pretax cost savings is required for the project to be profitable.
Pretax cost savings, as the name suggests, refers to the firm's income after expenses are deducted but before the taxes are considered. It can give a good view on the profitability of the firm.

In order to solve this, we must first compute the depreciation using the Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System (MACRS) method where the depreciation rate is not the same for every year. In the case of this problem, the rates are:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 1}&=0.3333\\
\text{Year 2}&=0.4445\\
\text{Year 3}&=0.1481\\
\text{Year 4}&=0.0741
\end{aligned}$$

To solve for the depreciation each year, we will simply multiply the initial investment by the corresponding factor. 

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$735,000 \times 0.3333\\[15 pt]
&=\$244,975.50
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation in year 1 is $\$244,975.50$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$735,000 \times 0.4445\\[15 pt]
&=\$326,707.50
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation in year 2 is $\$326,707.50$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$735,000 \times 0.1481\\[15 pt]
&=\$108,853.50
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation in year 3 is $\$108,853.50$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$735,000 \times 0.0741\\[15 pt]
&=\$54,463.50
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation in year 4 is $\$54,463.50$

For **Year 5**, we will calculate the after-tax salvage value instead. To do this, simply multiply the salvage value by 1 minus the tax rate:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax salvage value}&=\$85,000\times(1-0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$66,300
\end{aligned}$$

After tax, the salvage value is $\$66,300$

For the operating cash flow of **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=(\text{Pretax cost savings})\times(1-0.22)\\
&+0.22\times\$244,975.50\\[15 pt]
&=(\text{Pretax cost savings})\times0.78+0.22\times\$244,975.50
\end{aligned}$$

For the operating cash flow of **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=(\text{Pretax cost savings})\times(1-0.22)\\
&+0.22\times\$326,707.50\\[15 pt]
&=(\text{Pretax cost savings})\times0.78+0.22\times\$326,707.50
\end{aligned}$$

For the operating cash flow of **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=(\text{Pretax cost savings})\times(1-0.22)\\
&+0.22\times\$108,853.50\\[15 pt]
&=(\text{Pretax cost savings})\times0.78+0.22\times\$108,853.50
\end{aligned}$$

For the operating cash flow of **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=(\text{Pretax cost savings})\times(1-0.22)\\
&+0.22\times\$54,463.50\\[15 pt]
&=(\text{Pretax cost savings})\times0.78+0.22\times\$54,463.50
\end{aligned}$$

For the operating cash flow of **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=(\text{Pretax cost savings})\times(1-0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=(\text{Pretax cost savings})\times0.78
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow}&=\left[\text{Pretax cost savings}\times3.033966\right]+0.35\times\\
&+\dfrac{\$244,975.50}{(1.09)^1}+\dfrac{\$326,707.50}{(1.09)^2}\\
&+\dfrac{\$108,853.50}{(1.09)^3}+\dfrac{\$54,463.50}{(1.09)^4}\\
&+\dfrac{\$55,000+\$66,300}{1.09^5}
\end{aligned}$$

Simplifying the answer, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow}&=(\text{Pretax cost savings}\times3.033966)\\
&+\$217,829.33+\$78,836.68\\[15 pt]
&=(\text{Pretax cost savings}\times3.033966)+\$296,666.01
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting this value to the formula for net present value, where we will set the value of NP equal to zero, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
0&=-\$735,000-\$55,000\\
&+(\text{Pretax cost savings}\times3.033966)+\$296,666.01
\end{aligned}$$

Simplifying the equation by isolating the variable, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\$493,333.99&=(\text{Pretax cost savings}\times3.033966)
\end{aligned}$$

Divide both sides by $3.033966$, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Pretax cost savings}&=\dfrac{\$493,333.99}{3.033966}\\[15 pt]
&=\$162,603.66
\end{aligned}$$

In order for the project to be profitable, the pretax savings should be greater than $\$162,603.66$
